boardgame.name: Earth Under Siege: Flashpoint
boardgame.description:
Earth Under Siege: Flashpoint is a 1-4 player, co-op, sci-fi dungeon crawler where players complete covert missions against an invading alien force bent on subjugation of the entire Earth.

Setting:
The world is in chaos. Alien enemies are assaulting military bases all over the globe, obliterating any resistance before them. They attack indiscriminately and they show no mercy. They call themselves the Xethan, but where they come from is a complete mystery. They were simply not here one moment and initiating global conquest the next. If they came from space, there are no signs of it. None of the expected indicators of aliens traversing the stars, such as starships in orbit, have been observed. Indeed, the Xethan seem to possess no vehicles in their assaults at all. Instead, they rely on short range portal technology far beyond anything we’ve ever seen, which allows them to teleport short distances bypassing many of our defenses.

But the situation is much worse than just that. These Xethan are being aided by an insurgent faction of human terrorists that call themselves the Vormacht who seem to be working with these alien invaders and betraying their own species.

It has only been six months since the Xethan first appeared and they have already conquered large numbers of military bases all across Europe. If their momentum is not halted, the human race may well fall to these alien invaders. Someone must stop them.

We are that someone. Now is the time. While the world is still reeling from this unexpected assault, we have not been idle. We have come together, as a species, in recognition of this greater threat to our existence. We are no longer just splintered factions of rival groups; no longer separated by our differences. Humankind has never stood so together, united, arm in arm, moving together towards this one mission. We have become AEGIS, an allied force drawn from countries all over the Earth to stand against this threat. No longer will we stay on the defensive. Now is the time we stand up and show these Xethan that humankind will not fall so easily. Now, at this flashpoint in history, we fight back.

Gameplay:
Earth Under Siege: Flashpoint missions are heavily focused on stealth, covert actions, and sabotage. Players are Operatives of AEGIS, and their missions are focused on infiltrating enemy facilities, using every method available, such as cutting the power, using the ventilation shafts, making use of silenced weapons, and hacking into the enemy database.

Players develop their Operatives and HQ over the course of a 30+ mission campaign as they follow the story deeper and deeper until they uncover the true nature of the Enemy and where they came from.

Each round, players perform actions with their Operatives by exhausting one of their six action tokens until they run out of available tokens, or choose to pass. But players must be judicious in their use of their action tokens, because they normally only recover three of them each Refresh Phase.

Each Operative comes with a unique deck of Tactics cards which gives them access to powerful actions and effects. Each Player will develop these decks over the course of the campaign allowing them to tailor their gameplay to a particular style or focusing on specific combos.

boardgame.name: Hybris: Apollo
Hybris: Apollon
boardgame.description: An expansion for Hybris: Disordered Cosmos containing a new god.

boardgame.name: Name: The Celebrity Guessing Game
boardgame.description: Test your knowledge of well-known characters, actors, and celebrities, with the new Game Box - Name card game. Teams work together against the clock in this fast-paced guessing game, giving clues to find the answers, but there are some clues you MUST NOT use!

boardgame.name: The Devil in the Details
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Three hundred miles had already passed under the odometer, and another thousand lay ahead. Though his preternatural endurance kept him awake during the drive, Eric had gotten aMannegishi1late start, and already the nighttime roads stretched ahead like sinuous, blackened rivers. Suburbs had given way to farmsteads and rural landscapes, until at last the route was little more than a pothole-laden thread winding between hulking trees.

For a moment, Eric caught a glance of light reflected in a pair of large and luminous eyes, but they vanished into the brush as he sped by. Still, the sheer size of the saucer-shaped orbs stuck in his mind; no raccoon or opossum had eyes that large. He took a quick look over his shoulder, then returned his attention to the road.

As Eric turned his head forward, something fell out of the branches overhanging the road. A tremendous “KABANG!” reverberated through the car as it bounced off the hood, and Eric heard a drumroll sound of it hammering on the roof. He jerked the wheel to the right, and whatever it was flew off the other side of the car, spindly limbs flailing. The GTO crashed through the underbrush and slammed into a heavy tree, screeching to a stop.

After catching his breath, Eric turned to grab the Goat’s car cover in hopes of using its magic to restore the vehicle. With his back turned, he didn’t notice a slender hand reaching through the shattered windshield to wrap its fingers around Giantbane, Eric’s enchanted pistol...

User summary:

The Devil in the Details originally was published in Game Trade Magazine (Issue 110 - Apr 2009), and later was made available as a free download in PDF format.

boardgame.name: The Atua: The Polynesian Gods
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The history of The Atua begins with the Titans Rangi, an Avatar of Ehekatoyaatl, and Papa, an Avatar of Terra. These two Titans loved each other and gave birth to six gods, Tangaroa, Täne, Tu, Tawhirimatea, Rongo, and Haumia-Tiketike. Shortly thereafter, Rangi and Papa learned how to merge their Legend and become one. They left their Greater Titan parents, neither of which would accept them, and merged with Po, the Greater Titan of Night, casting both sky and earth into the darkness of night.

boardgame.name: Werewolf Execution
boardgame.description:
“When the moon is full, the werewolves begin to find their prey. When the sun is on, the villagers will start executions…”

Players on each side Villager or Werewolf try to win against the other side. Not like any board game hidden role, play/draw mechanism is used in Werewolf Execution to help players to interact, find information as well as increase vote to each other. Whoever reaches the full 7 votes or at the end of the day, the one who has the most votes, will be executed - be eliminated from the game.

Werewolf Execution does not need a moderator and can be played from 5 people up. Not only the main roles: Werewolf and Villager, there are 2 more roles - Angle and traitor to increase the difficulty and the interest of the game.

—description from the back of box

boardgame.name: Wasteland Mutant Origin Roller
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

“Hey mutant!”

Your blood boils at the term but you fight to choke back your tendency to get into fights when that word is tossed around. The Can is the best watering hole for miles around and your best place to meet up with a crew. You turn to see who’s yelling at you. To your surprise your rude new drinking companion is not a pureblood… but rather another mutant. And a tall, muscular one at that… you decide to try a bit of diplomacy.

“Yes?”

“So what’s your story? You headed anywhere? Taking the highway on foot alone or do you want company?”

“...So,” the Game Master turns to you, “what is your story?”

Mutant apocalypse role playing offers a rich, colorful world to explore and there’s no reason for the characters in the game to not be as equally colorful. Naturally there’s a desire to stay alive but what are the real reasons that the PCs or NPCs away from their home adventuring? What was their home like to begin with? What kind of gear do they start out with? Any weird personality features or odd cosmetic mutations?

This random roller product offers a collection of instructions, charts, and mutant creation sheets to help the GM or Player quickly flesh out the origins of mutant characters. The information is made to be as informative and yet as system generic as possible, allowing you to incorporate these creation rules into both published and home brewed game systems. Once you have used these rules you can further flesh out the character by incorporating what you have rolled up with this guide into your game’s regular character sheet information.

Included in the product are instructions and/or charts for creating the following details: Name, Gender, Age, Home Type, Purpose for Adventuring, Persona Trait, Cosmetic Mutation, Starting Weapon (melee), Starting Gear, Special Clothing Item, and a carried Trinket. There’s also a place on the mutant creation sheets for an image/illustration and additional background notes.

boardgame.name: 100 Seedy Starport Encounters 15
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Wandering through the streets, crowded hallways, and cramped businesses of dirty, seedy starports are an endless variety of encounters. Some are travelers from distant worlds while others are natives. This list provides a name for each encounter as well as a role and brief descriptive.

boardgame.name: 100 Wasteland Character Quirks
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This set offers a hundred different quirky features for wasteland characters (mutant, early after the bomb, etc.). These are all mostly gender neutral and most should not conflict with core character stats, etc. Included are certain behavioral patterns, manner of dress, things they collect, a curious companion pet, particular rituals, outlooks or fears, etc.

A system generic product usable for the game system of your choice- including your homebrewed project!

boardgame.name: 100 Cyber City Character Quirks
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

This set offers a hundred different quirky features for cyberpunk setting characters. These are all mostly gender neutral and most should not conflict with core character stats, etc. Included are certain behavioral patterns, manner of dress, things they collect, particular rituals, outlooks or fears, etc.

System generic so its ready for the game of your choice!

boardgame.name: Reef of the Dead Low Tide
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens past rippling waves, landing like dappled rainbows on dour underwater buildings. The tide is low, lapping against the reef the town is built on. Small circular dwellings stand, their rounded domes decorated in highlights of brass. Walkways are paved with tiles and spiralling walls, while seaweed clumps along the edges.
Different blue and gray sea life grows off the surrounding shelves, inhabited by various types of fish and a shark. Further down is only the blue of even more ocean, descending to unknown depths.

boardgame.name: Reef of the Dead
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens past rippling waves, landing like dappled rainbows on dour underwater buildings. Built into a dark reef, small circular dwellings stand, their rounded domes decorated in highlights of brass. Walkways are paved with tiles and spiralling walls, while seaweed clumps along the edges.
Different blue and gray sea life grows off the surrounding shelves, inhabited by various types of fish and a shark. Further down is only the blue of even more ocean, descending to unknown depths.

boardgame.name: Underwater Coral Village Low Tide
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens past rippling waves, landing like dappled rainbows on this partially-underwater village. The tide is low, lapping against the reef the town is built on. Small circular dwellings stand at different levels on the shelves, their rounded domes decorated in highlights of brass. Walkways are paved with tiles and spiralling walls, while seaweed clumps along the edges.
Different sea life grows off the surrounding shelves, inhabited by various types of fish and a shark. Further down is only the blue of even more ocean, descending to unknown depths.

boardgame.name: Tropical Beach
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens past rippling water, landing like dappled rainbows on a reef just a few steps from the sandy shore. Green seaweed clumps alongside red and blue coral, colorful anemones, and other sea life. Further down is only the blue of even more ocean, descending to unknown depths.
Fish and sharks dash back and forth amid rocks and plant life, while above white sand gives way to crumbling rock and steep stone cliffs. Palm trees sway gently in the breeze, while tropical undergrowth rustles below.

boardgame.name: The Great Reef
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens past rippling waves, landing like dappled rainbows on a sand and stone coral shelf. Green seaweed clumps alongside red and blue coral, colorful anemones, and other sea life. Fish and sharks dash back and forth amid rocks and plant life.
Further down is only the blue of even more ocean, descending to unknown depths.

boardgame.name: Kazumat's Fishing Village
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens past rippling water, landing like dappled rainbows on a reef just a fishing line’s throw from the pier. Green seaweed clumps alongside red and blue coral, colorful anemones, and other sea life. Further down is only the blue of even more ocean, descending to unknown depths.
Fish and sharks dash back and forth amid rocks and plant life, while above two fishing boats bob serenely. A pier leads to a series of dwellings, some with thatched palm frond rooves, others shingled. Barrels packed with palm oil and salted fish are piled near the homes.
White sand gives way to crumbling rock and steep stone cliffs. Palm trees sway gently in the breeze, while tropical undergrowth rustles below.

boardgame.name: Underwater Coral Village
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sunlight glistens past rippling waves, landing like dappled rainbows on this underwater village. Built into a coral shelf, small circular dwellings stand, their rounded domes decorated in highlights of brass. Walkways are paved with tiles and spiralling walls, while seaweed clumps along the edges.
Different sea life grows off the surrounding shelves, inhabited by various types of fish and a shark. Further down is only the blue of even more ocean, descending to unknown depths.

Adventure Seed

The last thing you remember is being thrown off the deck of a ship. White noise as you splashed into churning ocean waves, followed by sudden, deafening silence and a high-pitched ringing in your ears. You sunk down into the frothing sea, your lifeblood leaking like crimson ink into the water; tattered clothes drifting in the currents…
You wake, surprised to be alive, in a bed within a small hut—breathing water. A merwoman, noticing you, shyly explains that her people rescued you from the wreckage. To save your life they dissolved a magical pearl beneath your tongue, allowing you to breathe water. When they brought you here, she wrapped your wounds with healing seaweed. You’ve been asleep for days, and she suggests you remain here for a few more until you’re healed.
As you slowly recover, an elderly merman gives you tours of the town. It’s much larger than the sparse amount of merfolk within it, and they look thin and dishevelled. Your guide explains how his people have been at war with evil underwater races for years now, and that they’re losing. How, desperate, a band of young soldiers swam down to a ruined temple in search of an ancient weapon. They retrieved it, but something terrible was asleep down there. Something they woke up—the very same monstrosity that felled your ship.
While touring beautiful coral gardens, you overhear a group arguing about the destruction of nearby reefs from the monstrosity. Many insist that something must be done. But an elder barks that they have already discussed this, and the council has decided to leave the monster alone, trusting it will go away.
The next day, however, the monstrosity is sighted close to the village—heading straight for it. There aren’t many warriors left, and the merfolk can see from your body language and possessions that you’re no stranger to combat. They beg you to aid them in defending the town—if you do, they’ll reward you with more, highly valuable magic pearls.
WHAT’S HAPPENING? The monstrosity is the guardian of the ruined temple. It rages across the ocean, searching for the stolen weapon—destroying reefs and ships as it goes. Should you return it, the monster will go back to its slumber in the ruins. However, that would condemn the merfolk to losing the war, and allow the evil races they fight to invade the lands above. But if you don’t return it, the guardian will fight to the death to retrieve it.

boardgame.name: Abandoned Underground Stronghold
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sequestered away within the folds of a mountain stands a lookout tower. Few can imagine that it leads deep underground, into a forgotten stronghold. Past the cobwebs at the entrance a small stairwell winds deeper down, beyond a hallway and into chambers even further below.
The next floor is filled with ruined rooms. Rubble litters it, alongside fallen stone support beams. Even further down waits a series of chambers, one of them partially filled with water, and disjointed human bones…
What was this underground stronghold once used for, and why was it abandoned?

boardgame.name: Haunted Manor
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The roof of this haunted manor has caved in on itself, alongside sections of the floor; gaping like open, toothy grins. A giant spider has lain her eggs in the tallest tower, coating the surrounds in sticky cobwebs that both protect her young, and—perhaps—ensure their first meal.
Below, the first floor is filled with rubble and is partially overgrown with both wildflowers and ferns. Fallen support beams create unstable bridges across the gaps in the floor, while further down water pools in the cellar. The muck washes against human bones and even more rubble.
Deeper in, pillars hold up the sagging cellar ceiling. More broken support beams litter the floor, while thick wooden doors separate the many rooms. Far above, a large eagle has created its nest on what remains of the roof. From there, it can survey the surrounding ruins of the village, covered in rolling mist.

boardgame.name: Bleakbarrow's Crypt
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Sequestered away within the folds of a mountain stands a small tower. Few can imagine that it leads deep underground, into a sprawling crypt. Past the cobwebs at the entrance a small stairwell winds into a hallway, guarded by larger-than-life stone figures in robes. The floor is destroyed in sections, but beyond it, stairs lead even further down.

The next floor is filled with sarcophagi, some closed, but all too many broken open. A couple even have the honored dead arranged atop the stone. Small rooms branch off larger ones, while thin corridors wind their way between them chaotically.
More sections of the floor have fallen away in gaping grins, showing glimpses of the level below. Stone stairs lead down to it, with columns holding up the cracking stone ceiling. More rooms filled with the dead await, while water pools in another chamber—alongside a pile of rubble, and disjointed human bones.
Further in, a huge sarcophagus engraved with the figure of a sleeping king waits, his hands clasping a powerful sword.

boardgame.name: Haunted Orphanage
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

The roof of this rotting orphanage has caved in on itself, alongside sections of the floor; gaping like open, toothy grins. A giant spider has lain her eggs in the tallest tower, coating the surrounds in sticky cobwebs that both protect her young, and—perhaps—ensure their first meal.

Below, the first floor is filled with rubble and is partially overgrown with both wildflowers and ferns. Fallen support beams create unstable bridges across the gaps in the floor, while further down water pools in the cellar. The muck washes against human bones and even more rubble.

Deeper in, pillars hold up the sagging cellar ceiling. More broken support beams litter the floor, while thick wooden doors separate the many rooms. Far above, a large eagle has created its nest on what remains of the roof. From there, it can survey the surrounding dark forest, many of the trees sickly, mist occasionally rolling through.

Adventure Seed

You arrive at a ruined manor in a dark forest, at the behest of a man who discovered—on his alcoholic father’s deathbed—that the land was his inheritance, from his grandmother. But it has a bad reputation, so he’s paid you to inspect it and ensure it’s safe.
As you step into the overgrown courtyard, the ghosts of five adorable children materialize around you. They whine playfully, begging you to play a game with them. They’ve each hidden an object around the manor, and if you find it and return it to them, you win!

A short boy tells you that, far above, woody fingers clasp onto something that glitters with gold. One of the girls trills how, in the tallest tower, waits something soft, and comforting. A smaller girl adds that, under the water glistens a shining eye. Lastly, the ghost of the tallest boy advises that buried in the rubble, secrets are bound.
Should you find everything and return them, the children will squeal with delight. They’ll thank you, saying that’s the most fun they’ve ever had, and that they’re going to go now; before skipping off into the surrounding woodland and disappearing.

If you miss an item, the child responsible for it will grow angry and attack. If you’ve missed more than one, whichever children have been angered will coalesce into a more dangerous wraith; saying you’re just like the matron, that she didn’t like their games either. The more children there are coalescing, the deadlier the wraith will become.
WHAT’S HAPPENING? The manor used to be an orphanage, run by an abusive matron—the mother of the deceased, alcoholic father. She never let the kids play games, often beating them terribly for doing so. Until, one night, a fire destroyed the building and none survived.

The items the children have sent you to find are a golden pocket watch in the eagle’s nest, a teddy bear wrapped up in the spider’s nest, and a tiger’s eye gem in the flooded basement.

The last item, buried in a pile of rubble, was the journal of the orphanage’s matron. It details her struggles with the devilish, willfully misbehaving children who made her beat them. They knew no obedience, she writes, and surely would fail as adults in such a harsh world if she did not discipline them.

boardgame.name: Underdark Spider's Lair
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Giant cobwebs of differing sizes span the gaps of this misty, underdark spider’s lair. Their sticky strands cling to the crumbling stone walls of a seemingly-bottomless pit, filled with drifting mist. The webs are positioned under natural stone bridges for creatures who slip or wander foolishly into their grasp.
Many eyes watch them carefully for signs of movement. Pray nothing notices you as you wander the surrounding cliffs of bare, crumbling stone. Fallen rocks the litter the narrow walkways and are easily disturbed by moving feet.
You can hear clicks echoing up from the seemingly bottomless caverns.

boardgame.name: XANARTHRAXIA
boardgame.description:
https://store.steampowered.com/app/1073770/XANARTHRAXIA/

Stalwart knight, align yourself for battle! Synchronize the energetic patterns within XANARTHRAXIA's ancient glyphs and cleanse the land of evil in this bite-sized, casually competitive, RPG clicker.

boardgame.name: Zero Level Player's Guide
boardgame.description:
Rules for the Creation and Advancement of Zero Level Player Characters

Publisher's blurb:

Hello and welcome, adventurers and Game Masters!

In your hands is a guidebook for use with OSRIC, 1E compatible retro clones, and all editions of the world’s greatest roleplaying game! This guide focuses on the creation of new zero-level player characters, and new parties of such would-be adventurers.

I initially began creating such rules in 2017, as a helpful way of introducing new players to role-playing games and as a useful way to form a new adventuring party forged from a close knit group, e.g. all from one community and not just random strangers. I have published prior versions pf these rules, expounding on them with each iteration. The books were well received by my readers and became some of my best sellers. This then is a crystallization of those rules into their clearest, most direct restatement. This is a new zero level rules booklet just for players, focusing on what you need to know to prepare your new would-be hero for adventure!

The rules cover all aspects of zero-level character creation, including abilities; character archetypes (zero level "classes"); gear and equipment, spells (benedictions and cantrips), and much more. It even includes eight (8) play-tested pre-generated zero level player characters (two parties of four) for immediate use!

User summary:

A revised and expanded version of SR1: Zero Level Player Rules.
boardgame.rpg: Old School Reference and Index Compilation (OSRIC)

boardgame.name: Alchademy
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Alchademy is a puzzle game similar to other Alchemy-type games where players combine two items to make something new. It has items that can be used as ingredients for new items, and creations that can't be used to make anything new.

There are six different books, each which starts with three or four base ingredients. There are around fifty to eighty items to find in each book. The books may be purchased with in-game currency, but they also unlock on their own if players find all the combinations in the previous book.

The entire game feels like Halloween. The items themselves are combined in a cauldron. The art is amazingly good, very cute, and the creations are so unique!

Once the player gets used to the fact that each combination takes a lot of actual time to brew, it's quite fun. The game actually encourages the player to put it down and walk away while items are being combined in the cauldron. It's clearly aimed at children based on the comments that pop up on screen about now is a good time to finish your homework, binge your favorite show, or go for a walk outside.

boardgame.name: Llamasters: The Party Game
boardgame.description:
Designed for 2 - 5 players, Llamasters is premium entertainment created for card game revelers looking to nurture their relationships with one another.

There is more than one game mode to choose from, and it doesn’t matter if you’re a teenager, an old age pensioner, or anything in between: just about anyone can play and be transported to a wacky world of llamas.

The game is set in a savage Llama Kingdom, containing a plethora of comical llama characters - from royalty to thieves, and oracle readers to singers. There are also a bunch of other whimsical figures, such as killer sloths and armadillo guardians, that come with their own perks.

The aim of the game is to ultimately protect your kingdom, by ensuring your Llama King or Queen remains standing, which you can do by keeping their cards in your possession until the very end. You can also win by collecting 3 Buddha Llamas, but this can be reduced to 2 with the right combination of cards.

Gameplay involves tactical scheming through the use of various card types: Action, Magic, and Collectibles, and drawing a card from the deck ends your go.

It’s essentially the luck of the draw, but you must devise strategies, use your wit, and play combinations of cards to battle against other players, in an attempt to force them to remove their valuable cards and lose the round.

There are other dangers lurking within the deck too, as drawing certain cards can mean instant death. However, there are ways to deflect this and Llamasters offers its players several routes back towards victory even when you’re on the brink of giving up.

One of the unique points of the game is the use of augmented reality, which if used, can allow players to re-enter a round they have already been knocked out of. The augmented reality app also includes enchanting animations to complement the gameplay.

—description from the publisher
